ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to evaluate others' work, and a brief introduction to each of the concentrations in the art major.
General visual lexicon and literacy, some niche skills in zine making and printing
We learnt how to explore ideas in different mediums. However, we were not really taught how to formally use the mediums.

This course enhanced my vocabulary for discussing art and increased my familiarity with some artistic media such as printmaking and collage. It was also great to be able to discuss so many artists and ideas, so the insights I gained can't really be easily listed.
I think this class was really great for exposure to contemporary artists and the current field of art. In addition, I got to explore different mediums that I hadn't explored deeply before.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - flexible, fun experimental class culture, good assignments 
Weaknesses - poor time management sometimes, theory discussions werent very rigorous

The syllabus was good, however the in class experience did not live up to it. Class lacked energy and direction. We wasted at least 15 minutes every class waiting for people to show up, which was time we could have use to learn techniques to help our visual explorations.

This is a hard question. I would have loved more studio time to work, but I also understand that that cuts from discussion time, which was itself pretty scarce. This is one of those classes where there's never enough time.

Strengths: I think Alex was a great instructor and the structure of the course was really helpful. 
Weaknesses: There were a few readings that felt overly long and burdensome. In addition, we didn't really end up following the course outline in the syllabus, because we got behind pretty quickly. I think that might be unique to this weird semester, but there were some days I was a little unclear on the homework.

I really appreciated that the course allowed the students to be exposed to a extensive variety of different art fields. I also liked how open ended each assignment was and how open the resources were to engage with new studio spaces/materials such as the soa print shop

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not unless you have to take it for your major. For non-art majors, this may be a fun way to explore different art forms, but I did not really learn anything in this course.
Yes as a prerequisite or a casual art class! Didnt learn a ton, but had lots of fun!
Maybe, but my experience was uninspiring and I do not feel I have learnt anything. If the student wants to cruise, sure.
Yes! As long as a student doesn't have absolutely no interest in art, they will get something valuable from this course.
Yes! It was a low-workload way to experiment with different art forms with low pressure.
